instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message:
Got a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> when it came in it would not power on and no light on charger (brand new charger 85w).  When using older 85w charger green light shows solid but still won't power on.  After disconnecting the battery for 30 seconds and reconnecting the battery, the machine automatically boots (with dong).  Once machine boots (normal and quickly) battery shows X inside battery icon on menu bar.  Ghosting of display brightness being dimmed to black screen happens intermittently.  No signs of liquid damage.  Also customer reported a recent drop and HDMI port and USB port on right side now working.  

Any ideas?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: Also forgot to mention fans are running non-stop and at max speed immediately upon boot.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: Disconnect keyboard and try again. Is it a fake Chinese charger?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: It's a new Apple charger.  I will try unplugging the keyboard.  thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: I'm pretty sure it's a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A.  Can i see this model number on the board itself?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: Run ASD to see why fans are on full. Further I suspect a bad battery and the usual <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> problem, check the sticky on that.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message:
If it is anything like my own <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, it has a bad battery + the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> problem because my battery is bad and in parallel I get full fan speed intermittently.
EDIT: I'll try the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> repair this week when I have time to tear it apart as I use it for work all the time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: I cannot get it to boot into ASD.  And the only way I can get it to power on is plugging in the charger or (without the charger connected)  I can disconnect and then reconnect the battery and it will power on.  When it does boot up I can verify that the keyboard is working.  But when it is powered down the power button on the keyboard will not power it on.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: smc reset high? Voltage on ppbus g3h?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: I still say you have a fake 85W charger, a bad battery and possibly the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> issue.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Battery Issues
threads.message: I sent it in to the store.  Thanks guys.
